S1_1Q13:
In “The Morale Effects of Pay Inequality” by Emily Breza, Supreet Kaur, and Yogita Shamdasani, the authors study how paying workers different wages for the same job affects worker attendance, effort, and happiness as well as social cohesion within the firm. The paper builds upon a framework in which social preferences affect worker effort by allowing the wages of peers to affect worker morale. The authors conduct a month-long experiment that randomizes wage structure for manufacturing jobs for rural adult male workers in India during the lean season. Workers can either receive the same daily wage as the coworkers in their reference group or be paid differently based on their baseline productivity rank within their reference group. The authors exploit variation in baseline productivity and in observability of production tasks to study perceived justifications for differential pay. Using the randomized controlled trial in combination with a difference-in-differences empirical strategy, they find that pay inequality leads to lower attendance and output when it is difficult to observe peer productivity. However, when large differences in peer productivity are easy to observe, they do not find effects on attendance or output. The authors also use cooperative games and an endline survey to provide suggestive evidence that pay inequality leads to decreases in social cohesion when peer productivity is difficult to observe, but does not affect group cohesion when large differences in peer productivity are easy to observe. The paper contributes to literature in economics, sociology, psychology, and organizational behavior documenting that workers care about relative pay.

The scientific claims are mainly focused on estimating a causal relationship. Based on my reading, I think there are 3 causal claims investigated in the paper. First, pay inequality affects worker effort and attendance. Second, perceived justifications for pay differentials in terms of the observability of large differences in peer productivity mediate the negative effects of pay inequality. Third, pay inequality decreases social cohesion. The estimates apply to adult male workers in manufacturing jobs in rural India, but I think that the overall concepts can be broadly applied to behavioral tendencies of workers in labor markets around the world. The data come from a randomized experiment conducted by the authors and there are 12 tables and 5 figures in the main text of the paper. The authors use a randomized experiment in combination with difference-in-differences empirical strategies and a variety of robustness checks that restrict the sample and include different controls. Their preferred specification is a version of the difference-in-differences strategy given by equation (2) on p. 631.
S1_3Q1P1: The paper tested the effect of pay inequality on social cohesion among rural Indian workers, using a randomized controlled trial that included cooperative games and an endline survey. The main results for the first set of games show that relative to production units in which all workers received the same pay, production units with pay inequality built towers that were 9.376 cm shorter on average (with a standard error of 3.487).

S1_1Q13: Democracy does cause growth is a paper by Daron Acemoglu, Suresh Naidu, Pascual Restrepo and James Robinson. The paper uses panel data on 184 countries and creates an index measure of democracy from different sources to test whether there is a causal relationship between democracy and GDP growth. The paper uses three different methodologies: a dynamic panel model with country fixed effects, a semi-parametric matching based on observables and IV strategy based on regional waves of democratization. All three methods yield an impact of democratization on GDP per capita of 20-25% in the 25 years following a democratization event.

S1_1Q13: This paper aims to assess whether cash transfers conditional on school attendance lead to less dropout rates, better test scores (to capture the idea of human capital formation), less teenage pregnancy and less early marriage for school age girls compared to unconditional cash transfers. At the same time, the paper investigates the effects of unconditional cash transfers or cash transfers conditional on school attendance on these outcomes compared to no cash transfers (control).  The authors conduct a field experiment in Malawi, a poor south African country to be able to causally identify the effects. The population of interest is school age girls living in Developing countries. The authors collect data on their own based on 3 rounds of data collection. All 3 rounds include a household survey that captures household characteristics, such as assets owned by the household and number of people living in the household as well as the schooling status of the school age girl of interest, her sexual behavior, childbearing status and marriage status. The last two rounds of the data collection include a school survey that include information on how much the school age girl attended the school. Finally, the last round of data collection include tests that capture the school age girl's human capital and school ledgers that show daily attendance levels. Since this is a randomized field experiment, the authors used a simple regression model that includes covariates to capture the effect of the treatments. However, they conduct several robustness tests in addition to investigating balance across treatment groups and attrition to consolidate their findings. The authors randomize the treatments at the enumeration area level, which consists on average of 250 households. For covariates, the authors state "in all regressions, we include baseline values of the following as controls: a household asset index, highest grade attended, a dummy variable for having started sexual activity, and dummy variables for age. These variables were chosen because they are strongly predictive of schooling outcomes and, as a result, improve the precision of the impact estimates." For robustness checks, among other things, the authors look at how much self reported school attendance levels were biased by comparing it with school ledgers and teacher reported attendance, and the heterogeneity of program impacts for different age groups.

# Paper Summary of

## How many scientific claims can you identify in the paper? Provide a one sentece summary of the claims you seek to reproduce.  
I identify 4 claims in the paper, and intend to reproduce all of them.

1. The introduction of a large network of railroads reduces the trading costs (measured as the price difference of local commodities). This relationship is estimated such that an increase in 1% in effective distance leades to a 0.169% increase in trading costs (with bootstrapped 95 percent confidence intervals between 0,062 and 0.296).

2. Then, the paper estimates the effect of an increase in effective distance on trade flows across 47 regions for 15 commodities. It uses rain shocks to measure productivity and control for it. It finds an elasticiy of trade flows to trade costs of 1.603 (SE of 0.533).

3. The arrival of (any) railroads to a district has an effect of an increase on the district income by 16.4% (SE 0.049). Controling for location and year fixed effects.  

4. To tease out how much of the increase in income is due to an increase in trade (remove things like better TK brought by the RR) the paper uses the previous estimates to calibrate a model. Doing this it suggests that about 52% (of the 16% increase in income) is due to trade. This estimate is obtained by comparing coefficients of RR on adjusted income without (0.258) and with (0.124) controls for controls for trade (0.52 = (0.258 - 0.124)/0.258))

## Would you classify the claims as causal, descriptive (e.g., estimating a population's descriptive statistic), or something else?  
Mainly causal. A large reduction in transportation costs (large = something that drops costs by an elasticity of 0.169) can increase income by about 8% (0.52 * 0.164) through trade.

Present day countries countries that are potentially facing mayor reductions in transportation costs

Districs (for trade costs) and regions (for effect on income) of northern colonial india that trade salt and 14 other commodities.

S1_1Q8: Active labor market participants in Kolkata, India, who are up to work for daily wages.
S1_1Q9: Given the nature of the experiment, this can be generalized to the labor market in all developing countries (possibly developed countries as well).
S1_1Q13:
This paper investigates whether labor market participants hold information about others in their private social network that could be useful for firms in their hiring processes. Firms are always interested in hiring workers who are most apt for the tasks they will need to perform. Observable characteristics may help firms screening participants. However, individual workers who know the task at hand and their peers in the labor market may prove useful. They may have access and knowledge to characteristics of job candidates’ that the firm cannot observe. The firm can improve its hiring process if it can get workers to share this knowledge they have from their peers. 

This paper uses a randomized control trial to test whether current workers recommend good job candidates to a daily work setting that the researchers created in Kolkata, India. Their setting is a lab where individuals are asked to perform cognitive demanding tasks. The whole work interaction is supposed to take no longer than two hours between a questionnaire and the cognitive task. After completing the activity, all workers are asked to bring a friend or relative to the lab “who would be good at the task [they] just completed.” On top of this information, the researchers randomized whether workers are offered a referral payment based on the performance of their referee’s, or simply on the referee actually coming to the lab. In addition, the researchers varied different payment amounts in each category.

The paper finds that high-performing individuals are indeed able to refer the firm to other high-performing workers, but they only do so when they are incentivized for it. On the other hand, low-performing workers were not able to refer the firm to high-performing workers. The firm enjoyed a performance premium from high-performance workers who were referred-in relative to the performance the firm itself would be able to achieve by selecting based on observable characteristics such as age, income, and education. 

Given their RCT design, the authors use a least-squares regression analysis to arrive at their estimates. The data is primary, collected by the authors for this study. The population for the study started with 561 Original Participants - a random sample drawn from door-to-door solicitation in a peri-urban residential area of Kolkata. Original Participants then invited other participants to the lab (their referrals), as per the study’s design.

S1_1Q13:
Using long-run individual-level panel data from Kenya and Indonesia, this paper shows that the productivity gap across non-agricultural workers and agricultural workers, and the productivity gap across workers in urban and rural areas, are largely diminished once individual fixed effects are included. To follow these claims, the paper asserts that the productivity gap between sectors is a reflection of worker selection. The authors support these causal claims using mean difference estimates, regression-adjusted mean difference estimates, and fixed-effects panel data estimation. In the theoretical portion of the paper, the authors demonstrate that the productivity gap can be broken down into a labor supply gap, a human capital gap, differences in observed components of worker human capital, and a productivity residual, which is the key parameter of interest.


The estimates from this paper apply to working individuals in Kenya and Indonesia but can perhaps be extrapolated to describe conditions in other low-income, populous (or even less populous) countries. The main results which rely on fixed effect estimates may be biased because the preferred estimate includes only the individuals who have earnings observations in both sectors. The paper uses 5 rounds of the Indonesian Family Life Survey (IFLS) spanning the years 1993 to 2015, which is representative of 83% of the country’s population, and the 3 rounds of the Kenya Life Panel Survey (KLPS), which covers the timeframe of 2003 to 2014. Both datasets have high tracking rates and include detailed information on formal and informal sector employment.

There are 6 tables, 3 figures, and around 50 inline results reported in the main body of the paper

S1_1Q13:
In The Economic Origins of Conflict in Africa, McGuirk and Burke identify the causal effect of (plausibly exogenous) global crop price variation on local conflict in Africa. The authors describe their context as one where agricultural products comprise a high share of household production and consumption. This summary of the paper identifies 7 scientific claims, 5 of which provide causal estimates and 2 of which are descriptive/predictive. 

In terms of the first 4 claims, the authors test: (1) the effect of higher domestically produced crop prices on factor conflict; (2) the effect of higher consumer crop prices on factor conflict; (3) the effect of higher domestically produced crop prices on output conflict; and (4) the effect of higher consumer crop prices on output conflict. (Given some level of subjective judgment in identifying claims, one might consider (1) and (2) to be one claim and (3) and (4) to be a second claim, in the same way that (5) – see below – is considered as a singular claim.) The analyses for these claims are at the cell-year level, where the grid cells are 0.5 x 0.5-decimal degrees and cover the African continent (including Madagascar) and the period of analysis is from 1989 to 2013 (with slight variations across tests, depending on the data sources). The main econometric specifications are estimated with a linear probability model; for the main results, both Conley and two-way standard errors are reported. The primary data sources consist of the UCDP GED dataset (Uppsala Conflict Data Program Georeferenced Event Dataset) for factor conflict (covering 1989-2010), the ACLED dataset (Armed Conflict Location and Event Dataset) for output conflict (covering 1997-2013), global crop prices from the IMF’s (International Monetary Fund) International Finance Statistics series and the World Bank’s Global Economic Monitor (1989-2013), crop-specific agricultural land cover from the M3-Cropland project, and food consumption data from the FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization). (Note: There are additional data sources, such as luminosity from satellite images and measures of urbanity, which enter in the analyses for robustness checks and/or heterogeneity analysis.) In establishing these claims, the authors additionally carry out a number of robustness checks for their main results with respect to factor conflict and output conflict (display items corresponding to these checks are located in the paper’s appendix). The results are robust to the inclusion of cell-level controls for an oil price index, a mineral price index, temperature and precipitation, and mostly year fixed effects. The results are also qualitatively robust to a secondary suite of checks, including but not limited to varying the Conley standard error kernel cutoffs and estimation via a conditional fixed effects logit model.

In addition to the above, the authors present a fifth claim (5), which tests the effects of higher (domestically produced and consumer) crop prices on output conflict, where output conflict in this case is measured via survey data (i.e. in terms of theft or physical assault) from Afrobarometer and other data sourced as above. Given the reduced coverage of Afrobarometer data, this analysis is at the cell-year level for grid cells covering 19 countries in Africa, for the period from 1999 to 2009. The specification uses a triple-difference approach. 

In addition to estimating the causal relationships of income shocks on conflict, McGuirk and Burke make two other main claims that are descriptive/predictive. The first of these other claims (6) is to demonstrate that relying on country-level data and/or “catch-all conflict and price measures,” as the prior literature does, will lead to misrepresented estimates of the causal relationship between crop prices and conflict in Africa. The other claim (7) provides an estimate of the predicted impact of future price movements on factor conflict and output conflict – the prediction uses projections of future grain prices from IFPRI (the International Food Policy Research Institute) and provides estimates in a scenario with and without climate change. 

Overall, evidence for the authors’ main scientific claims is presented through 7 tables, 7 figures, and approximate 55 inline results in the paper’s main body; the results are further bolstered by 30 tables and 7 figures in a separate appendix.

S1_1Q13: This study is a 7-year follow up of an intervention meant to provide CBT (cognitive behavioral therapy) as a treatment against depression for perinatally depressed mothers in rural Pakistan. The study randomly allocated CBT sessions to a treatment group of XX mothers along with 16 home visits by lady health workers (LHWs) for all women in the sample for 9 months (starting 3 months prior to delivery). This paper sets out to show causally that treating depression can also affect parental involvement and investments. These estimates help measure an ITT (intention-to-treat) effect from being assigned to the CBT arm of the intervention, as it accounts for imperfect compliance into the treatment (not all mothers assigned to CBT have attended all the sessions).   \nUsing the same sample as the original study and returning 7 years post-program, this paper finds persistent benefits of the intervention in terms of mental health and depression of the mother. It estimates the impact of the program using the initial randomization and shows an increase in the mother’s financial empowerment, and parental investments both in time and money, with no detectable differences in fertility or parenting style. However, it finds no difference in child outcomes in terms of child development for both the index child (targeted at birth) or their sibling. This paper’s estimation strategy is straightforward as it uses the initial randomization of the intervention, and implements the following robustness checks: computing Lee bounds as well as inverse probability weighting (for doubly robust estimators) to account for attrition in the 7-year follow-up sample based on the baseline data; correcting for multiple hypothesis testing by using randomization inference. \n

Summary
Alsan, Marcella. 2015. "The Effect of the TseTse Fly on African Development."

The paper's four broad hypotheses (associated with 12 claims total) are primarily focused on estimating a historical, causal relationship between TseTse suitability and the ability of Africans to generate an agricultural surplus. In particular the author provides empirical evidence that ethnic groups inhabiting areas with high TseTse suitability were less likely to: (1) adopt certain agricultural practices, (2) have high population densities (3) have politically centralized institutions and (4) rely on subsistence strategies dependent on animal husbandry. 

The focus population as a whole can be generalized to ethnic groups living in precolonial Africa. The paper’s main estimates more closely apply to the 533 out of 1,267 ethnic groups represented in the Ethnographic Atlas database which inhabited Africa during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The Ethnographic Atlas database provides the main data set used for analysis, and contains the historical features of ethnic groups prior to European settlement.  The Ethnographic Atlas database which contains the historical features of ethnic groups prior to European settlement provides the main data set used for analysis.

The first generalized hypothesis (ethnic groups inhabiting high TseTse-suitable areas were less likely to adopt certain agriculture practices) is associated with three claims pertaining to the use of Intensive agriculture, large domesticated animals, and the use of the plow. The display items associated with these three claims are the first three rows of Table 1 (of which includes four separate OLS specifications for each claim). The author’s preferred specification is reported in column 4 of Table 1. After reporting the main results for each claim in section III, the author reserves a significant portion of the remainder of the paper for several robustness checks.
S1_4Q1:
In addition to effects on certain agricultural practices, the paper also tests effects on subsistence strategies. The results are presented in Table 2 and imply a one standard deviation increase in the TSI is associated with a (statistically significant) 0.216 percentage point increase in reliance on hunting. Additionally, gathering is shown to be positively correlated with the TSI and this correlation (as postulated by the author) may be due to complementarities between hunting and gathering. 

Regarding this postulation, I’d be interested in a possible robustness check constructing and testing the effects on a third categorical variable for reliance on terrestrial foraging (hunters and gatherers combined). For example, this new categorial variable for terrestrial foraging could assign the lowest values (e.g. numbers closer to 1) to ethnic tribes with both a high reliance on hunting (e.g. hunting=100) and a relatively low reliance on gathering (e.g. gathering=1). In turn, the highest values could be assigned to ethnic tribes with similar reliances on both hunting and gathering (e.g. hunting=gathering=50). 

After tackling the challenge of constructing an ideal categorical variable for reliance on terrestrial foraging, I could then conduct analysis under the same specifications used in Table 2. The idea for this potential robustness check is to create a measure which may be capable of revealing previously concealed complementarities between hunting and gathering. A significant, positive coefficient for terrestrial foraging could provide supportive evidence for the positive correlation of reliance on gathering with the TSI (a main result reported in column 3 of Table 2) being due to complementarities between hunting and gathering, as conjectured (but not tested) by the author.

S1_1Q13: The paper seeks to estimate a population parameter, the level of p-hacking and publication bias in top economics journals. Four scientific claims are investigated: 1) the identification of the level of p-hacking and publication bias; 2) determining how the level varies based on the econometric method used and author characteristics; 3) determining how the level varies based on whether or not the paper went through a review process; and 4) if the level changes over time. The population studied is all papers published in the top 25 economics journals for the years 2015 and 2018. The data sources are all of the aforementioned papers, using keywords in text searches to sort papers by econometric method used, and also manually removing papers by certain criteria, e.g. papers that 'employed a sub-method that alters researcher freedoms.' Characteristics of each paper's authors were collected manually by searching for their curriculum vitae. Data from Brodeur et al. (2016) was also used.\n\nThe researchers mainly work with the distribution of test statistics in all the above articles. To quote the statistical methods used to examine each claim: 'First, using randomization tests to identify discontinuities in the probability of a test statistic appearing just above or below a statistical threshold. Second, we apply caliper methods to compare test statistics within narrow bands around thresholds. Third, we compare each distribution to its own calibrated counterfactual.' The researchers also attempt to estimate the amount of distortion in the distribution of test statistics by 'applying a step function at significance thresholds to the conditional probability of publication.'

S1_1Q13:
“The Morale Effects of Pay Inequality,” a paper by Emily Breza, Supreet Kaur, and Yogita Shamdasani uses RCT survey data from manufacturing firms to estimate the causal effect of wage inequity on worker morale. Morale is measured in a number of ways. The first, and primary, set of measures are worker attendance, and (conditional on this) change in worker productivity; The second set measure social cohesion: performance in team games (the height of a tower, and the number of items correct in each of two cooperative puzzle games) and measures of network formation. The study was conducted in rural India with workers employed in low-skill manufacturing jobs.

Tables 4 gives the main results; table 5 gives the effects over time; tables 6 and 7 offer suggestive evidence of mediating effects of perceived justifications; table 8 gives the effects of higher absolute pay among workers who received the same wage as others in their unit; tables 9-11 give effects on social cohesion; and table 12 gives workers’ assessment of how fair their wages were. Each of these tables tests a number of claims (each associated with a p-value), for a total of 195. However for the purpose of this exercise, I refer to a "claim" as the group of claims tested in a given table, for a total of 9.

In this exercise, I will reproduce tables 9-11, which ascertain social cohesion and comprise 34 of these claims, technically. But 3 tables, or "claims" for the purpose of this exercise.

S1_1Q13: This paper presents descriptive claims, some of which can have a causal interpretation, regarding the degrees of effort, diagnosis accuracy and correctness of treatment for public and private medical providers in rural India. The paper offers three main results: first, private providers exert significantly higher effort than public providers using different metrics and perform similarly on diagnosis and treatment; second, providers with private and public practices showed higher effort and higher treatment accuracy in their private practices, which can be interpreted as the causal effect of being treated in a private practice relative to being treated in a public practice holding the practitioner characteristics constant; finally, the paper shows that there is a positive correlation between fees, quality and effort for private providers. The paper focuses on a sample of the population of medical providers in the rural state of Madhya Pradesh. However, this sample is not completely representative since villages with no paved roads are dropped, and certain types of medical providers (those who do home visits) are excluded. Nevertheless, the results can probably be extrapolated to other rural areas in India among providers with physical clinics, and could also apply to settings outside of India with similar institutional contexts (low regulation in the private sector and a similar public healthcare system). The paper’s data is an audit composed of 1,100 unannounced visits to 224 providers (final sample size), as well as a census of provider and household characteristics in the sampled villages. The paper displays 8 tables, 4 figures and around 105 in-line results. The results come from linear regressions on outcomes measuring quality and effort in interactions, and a focus of the main regressor of whether the practice is public or private. The author’s preferred specification includes secret patient, case and market fixed effects, which leads to an interpretation of the results as relative performance within a market.  The author checks the robustness of the results against using observed interactions rather than interactions with secret patients (audits), provides evidence that differences between private and public practices are not due to statistical discrimination, and shows that results hold for each type of condition being tested (out of three).

S1_1Q13:
The paper examines the causal relationship between the application of deworming interventions and quality of life measurements. There were four claims:
- The treatment group experienced 305 USD PPP more consumption, 80 USD PPP greater individual earnings, and 239 USD PPP greater household earnings.
- The treatment group had 0.14 USD PPP greater hourly earnings.
- The treatment group was 0.04% more likely to live in urban areas and worked 1.91 more nonagricultural weekly hours.
- The social IRR is 37% and the 25 year, 10% discount rate NPV is USD PPP 230.71.
These estimates apply to a group of Kenyan schools, but can be generalized to subjects of deworming interventions in low-income countries. The econometric method is a linear regression where individual outcomes are predicted from cost sharing/saturation indicators, individual and school covariates, and T indicates treatment.

S0_1Q1P3: Marcella Alsan
S1_1Q8: The main population that is the focus of the paper here is the population of the African subcontinent. The paper studies the historical roots of African development and the whole region is taken into account as the Tsetse fly is endemic to the continent.
S1_1Q9: The results of the paper have limited applicability outside of the African continent as the tsetse fly is not found in any other part of the world, including other tropics.
S1_1Q13:
While there has been speculation about the role of Tsetse fly in historically structuring Africa’s political development, Alsan’s paper is the first to empirically estimate the effect of the fly on Africa’s precolonial agriculture, population density and institutions. By using the specific, non-monotonic temperature and humidity requirements for the Tsetse fly to thrive, the author develops a Tsetse Suitability Index (TSI) which helps deal with two important issues affecting the empirical study of the role of the fly on African development: 1) the absence of reliable data on the Tsetse distribution in the precolonial period and 2) the correlation between tsetse spread and better institutions that could have controlled the population to some degree. 

The claim in the paper is causal, where the author uses the following precolonial outcomes: 1) agricultural practices which includes domestication of animals, intensive agriculture practices, female participation and plow use, 2) urbanization which is measured by population density, 3) institutions measured by indigenous slavery and centralization. 
The main sources of data for the paper are historical climatological variables using data from the NOAA’s 20th Century Reanalysis and suitability for rain-fed agriculture from the FAO (2002). Additionally, the author uses the Ethnographic Atlas which has cross-sectional data on ethnic groups in Africa prior to European colonization.

The authors results are estimated using OLS and the main equation is using the above outcomes as dependent variables, the TSI as the independent variable, and a vector of climate related tropics variables. The author also uses alternative Tsetse suitability indices as well as alternative clustering methods to check the robustness of the results. Finally, the author simulates historical African development in a setting with a low burden and prevalence of the Tsetse fly indicating that Africa would have had some increases in centralization and intensive agricultural practices.
S1_4Q1: The paper covers some important robustness checks to account for threats to the validity of the TSI. In Table 3, the author undertakes a series of robustness checks by causing slight perturbations to the formula such as shifting temperatures one standard deviation above or below. The author also uses a different and more straightforward version of the TSI to re-estimate the results. I will be running these robustness checks but have no new ones I recommend.
S1_3Q1P1: The paper tests the effect of the TseTse (measured through the TSI) on precolonial African development outcomes of agricultural practices (domestication of animals, intensive agriculture, female participation, and plow use), urbanization measured by population density, and institutions measured by indigenous slavery and centralization. The main result shows that a one standard deviation increase in the TSI decreases the probability of an ethnic group having large domesticated animals by 23 percentage points, a 9 percentage point decrease in intensive cultivation and a 6 percentage point decrease in plow use.

S0_1Q1P2: Rural Roads and Local Economic Development
S0_1Q1P3: Sam Asher, Paul Novosad
S1_1Q1: Rural Roads and Local Economic Development - PSET
S1_1Q8: Villages In India around 1000, 500 and 250 inhabitants that were targeted fr all-weather road connection by the Prime Minister’s Village Road Program (PMGSY)
S1_1Q9: Villages in the low-income world. Villages in the now developed world in a historical context (when they were not developed)
S1_1Q13:
This paper attempts to estimate the causal effects of road construction (all-weather road in particular) on development outcomes broadly. The paper focuses on five main general development indicators: (i) transportation services, (ii) sectoral allocation of labour, (iii) employment in non farm village firms, (iv) agricultural investment and yields, and (v) income, assets, and predicted consumption. These are the five claims tested by the papers. In order to better study and understand each one of them, the authors study them using an index of their own creation, as well as individual outcomes within each of these categories, which provide details on heterogeneous effects within each claim.

 The paper takes advantage of the Prime Minister’s Village Road Program (PMGSY), which started in 2000 in India, to estimate the desired effects. The estimation is carried out using Regression Discontinuity Design (RDD) together with an instrumental variables (IV) strategy, taking advantage of the fact that road construction under PMGSY would link villages that met some population requirements: 1000, 500 or 250 inhabitants depending on the state. In practice there were also other criteria that could lead a village to get all-weather road connection. Hence, the authors explore a fuzzy RDD. Moreover, the above thresholds were not always respected out of discretion by government officials. To overcome this issue, the authors focus their analysis in states for which they could verify, following conversations with government officials, that threshold carried some weight. The RDD was used as the first stage in the IV strategy (it was used to extract an exogenous component of roads impacting on development outcomes).

S1_1Q13: In rural Madhya Pradesh, India, private providers are less qualified than public providers, yet many people still opt to pay for a private provider instead of receiving care from higher educated public providers for little to no cost. This is an interesting puzzle that the paper attempts to investigate by using audit data for healthcare providers to assess the quality of public versus private healthcare. By sending standardized patients (SPs) to present one of three medical conditions (unstable angina, asthma, and dysentery), the paper is able to construct reliable and comparable measures of quality. Each condition has an associated checklist of questions and examinations needed to arrive at a correct diagnosis. Provider quality is measured based on adherence to this checklist, correctly diagnosing the condition, and prescribing correct treatment. The paper has two main samples: a representative sample of public and private providers and a “dual sample” consisting of public providers who also operate their own private practices. For each of these samples, the paper uses OLS, regressing measures of quality on an indicator for being a private provider (or for seeing the SP in their private practice, for the dual sample). The preferred empirical specification pools the three medical cases and includes SP, case, and district fixed effects. This analysis yields two descriptive claims presented by the paper. Firstly, private providers exert higher effort in the representative sample and, in the dual sample, providers exert more effort within their private practice. Secondly, despite this difference in effort, private and public providers recommend correct treatments equally often. The paper explains this by suggesting that private providers exert more effort to compensate for their lower qualifications. However because of their lower medical knowledge, private providers are more likely to ask “low-discrimination” checklist items, so that their higher effort yields lower productivity returns. Lastly, the paper looks at the correlation between payment and measures of quality, resulting in its third main claim. The market rewards providers who “do more”, which includes doing more good things such as spending more time with a patient, asking more checklist questions, but also doing more unnecessary things such as prescribing antibiotics needlessly. The public sector, in contrast, does not award these factors, and wages for public providers are correlated with education and experience (proxied by age). To investigate the plausibility of external validity, the paper also collects observational data on real patient visits to public and private providers, and finds that the results hold for medical cases beyond the three conditions presented in the audit study.
S1_3Q1P1: The paper estimated the differences in effort exerted by public and private healthcare providers, using audit data. The main results show that private providers scored 0.67 standard deviations higher on the IRT-scaled score, which looks at checklist adherence, but places higher weights on more essential questions. Additionally, private providers spent 1.5 more minutes per patient (62 percent higher than public providers) and completed 7.4 percentage points more items on the checklist (47 percent higher than public providers).

S0_1Q1P2: The Economic Origins of Conflict in Africa
S0_1Q1P3: Eoin McGuirk, Marshall Burke
S1_1Q8: The paper focuses on the African continent as a whole.
S1_1Q9: The paper examines the impact of (global) food price shocks on (local) violence, across Africa. The main results suggest that higher prices might decrease factor conflict (the control of territory), while increasing the likelihood of output conflict (control of surplus), in food producing areas. In non-food producing areas, the results suggest that higher prices might increase both type of conflicts. This main result might generalize to other parts of the world -- including parts of Asia and parts of South America. However, in this paper, the mechanism relies on the fact that agricultural products account for a much higher share of household production and consumption in Africa, more than in many other parts of the world -- this stylised fact might not generalize as easily.
S1_1Q13:
This paper examines the impact of global food price shocks on local occurences of violence. Traditionally, the relationship between economic shocks and violence suffer from a simultaneity issue, and isolating causal relationships has been challenging. The existing literature on the topic is thus fairly inconclusive. In this paper, the authors' approach allows for the identification of causal mechanisms, by distinguishing between factor conflict (the control of territory) and output conflict (the appropriation of surplus).  By doing so, the authors are able provide clear hypotheses for how global (exogeneous) changes in prices might affect the occurence of these two types of conflict at a sub-national level. The authors examine four claims in particular; these are: i) Higher domestically produced crop prices reduce "factor conflict" ii) Higher consumer crop prices increase factor conflict, iii) an increase in domestic crop prices increases output conflict, and 4) higher consumer prices increase output conflict. 

The paper relies on a number of data sources, for the main analysis. (I do not list additional sources used for secondary analysis here). Data on conflict is sourced from the Uppsala conflict database,  the ACLED project, and Afrobarometer survey data. Data on prices is collected from the IMF and World Bank databases. Additionally, in order to construct the producer price index, high resolution spatial data from the M3-Cropland project is used. Consumer price index data is obtained from the FAO's food balance sheets. 

Overall, the main body of the paper has 7 tables,  7 figures, and 6 inline results. The authors use slightly different specifications for the factor conflict and output conflict results. The preferred specification for the main analysis is a linear probability model in both cases. A number of robustness tests are conducted, to examine the validity of the results. Some of the robustness tests focus on the additional of additional covariates, while another set of tests focuses on alternative definitions of the outcome variable. Finally, a number of tests examine the stability of the results in response to changes in the data resolution, different specifications for the Conley standard errors, and the addition of weights to the regressions.

S1_1Q13:
This paper seeks to estimate the causal relationship of relative pay on labor supply, output, and social cohesion. The authors employ a randomized controlled trial among manufacturing workers in India to generate exogenous variation in relative pay and perceived justification for pay differences. Specifically workers are randomly assigned to units of three. Units are then randomly assigned to produce different products and to one of four wage structures: either pay disparity, where each worker is paid a different wage depending on their baseline productivity rank within the unit, or compressed wages, where all unit members receive the same daily wage that is equivalent to either the low, medium, or high wage in the pay disparity group. Furthermore, the random assignment of workers to units and units to tasks generates exogenous variation in perceived justification for pay differences by generating exogenous variation in the ratio of the wage difference to the productivity difference and because production tasks differ significantly in the observability of output. At endline, the authors conduct two games to measure social cohesion and cooperation among coworkers. The authors collect observational data on productivity, including on attendance and output, data from the endline cooperation games, as well as endline survey data for the empirical analysis. 

In the estimation strategy, the authors employ a differences-in-differences approach, comparing workers of the same relative rank and absolute pay but with different relative pay. The authors’ preferred specification includes worker fixed effects, day-by-round fixed effects, quadratic controls for experience, controls for neighboring units, as well as pre-period controls and irrelevant worker controls to improve precision. Estimations of the preferred specification are reported for both attendance and output as the dependent variable, as well as pooled across all ranks or estimated separately for each rank. The authors conduct a number of robustness checks, including testing the sensitivity of the results to dropping irrelevant workers, dropping neighboring unit controls, dropping individual fixed effects, and dropping pre-period observations. 

Based on the methodology and data, the paper makes three main scientific claims. One, pay disparity reduces labor supply for workers, as measured by attendance and output. Notably, attendance also decreases for workers receiving a relatively higher pay than their coworkers, without improving output for these workers. Two, when the rationale for pay differences is clear to workers, these negative effects are mitigated. Three, pay disparity reduces social cohesion, which suggests this may be a key channel through which pay disparity affects productivity. The main paper includes many display items to support these claims, including 11 tables, 3 figures, and 38 inline results. In addition, the appendix includes 14 display tables and 4 display figures.

S4_1Q1_4: I think this variation is sensible because it tests the sensitivity of the main results on the effects of pay disparity to functional form assumptions. In the original specification, the authors include controls with both experience and the square of experience to allow for task-specific non-linearities in returns to experience. However, the choice to include only experience and experience squared terms, rather than higher order terms, is arbitrary and imposes implicit functional form assumptions. Note that these controls are only relevant in the specifications that do not include individual fixed effects.

S4_1Q1_7:
Detailed results from this robustness check are included in the replication code in the R and R Markdown files in the Github repository. Overall, the results from this variation are very similar to the original results, suggesting that the original results are not driven by functional form assumptions. 

Specifically, in Table IV Column 1 Panel A, the original coefficient estimate on posttreat for prodnorm was -0.311 (0.110) which was significant at the 1% level. In this variation, the coefficient estimate is -0.310 (0.110) which is also significant at the 1% level. Similarly, for Column 2 Panel A the original coefficient estimate on posttreat for attendance was -0.115 (0.026) which was significant at the 1% level and in this variation the estimated coefficient is -0.114 (0.025) which is also significant at the 1% level. Similarly, for Column 5 Panel A the original coefficient estimate on posttreat for output conditional on attendance was -0.089 (0.094) which was not significant at conventional levels, and this variation produces an estimate of -0.088 (0.093) which is also not significant at conventional levels. 

Similar patterns result from estimating Table IV Panel B using this variation. In all cases, the estimates of the coefficients, standard errors, and corresponding levels of statistical significance from the variation are very similar to the original results.
